/COMMIT_MSG.message: How do we make sure the cache isn't old?
Here the "host" is not the build server like ala-lpggp3, it is the container "builder". Command "downloder" also runs on it and use the same repository sources.

We also have to guard against the inverse scenario, in which the builder was constructed from NEWER packages than those that we will be using to build StarlingX.  Remember that our packages are locked down to specific versions that will likely lag upstream.

Here the apt cache of the "builder" is also used to "download -b -s xxx", each time before we build a project we need to download firstly, and before that, we need to make sure the apt cache is newest. Then we will start to "build" packages or images, so at that time point, the apt cache should not out of date.

On the other hand, if the apt cache is out of date, that means the package list file and those packages we downloaded are also out of date, need to be updated. With that updated, we will get a newest apt cache.

There is no limit to how long a builder container remains alive, so I am still concerned about 'old' content. Especially as we move to proper k8s organisational builds where the builder containers will become service endpoints and remain active for extended durations (just like a web server in k8s).

Here the purpose we introduce the bullseye repository is getting the runtime depend relationships between binary packages. The purpose of this module is to get the build order of source packages. For example we have two source packages to build, A and C. Source package A directly build depend on binary package b1, while package b1 is runtime depend on binary package x2 and x2 is runtime depend by c3, whilec3 is build from source package C. Thus we will build source package C firstly, then A. Here we introduce the bullseye's repository is to get the key information like "b1 runtime depend on c3".

So in this use case the version is not critical and upstream repository is good enough. Even if we choose lower version source packages, it will also work in order.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: In original design, we didn't suppose we can run in a Debian bullseye environment thus construct a "root" folder and related "sources.list" for apt cache. Now, add a switch/choice to use the apt cache of the host. By default, use the host's apt cache.

1、有两个疑问，一个是怎么确定主机的系统的缓存和容器的缓存时兼容的？比如主机是centos系统？
2、如果以后版本跨度大，怎么保证主机的缓存，使用容器的呢？

1、这里的host指的不是编译服务器，而是该程序的运行时”主机“，实际上是一个名为”builder“的容器，这是一个bullseye（Debian） image，整个环境是专门为Debian编译服务的，上面天然有bullseye的官源。也就是我们需要的源。至于服务器是什么系统倒是没什么关系，无论是Debian，Ubuntu还是Centos，都无所谓了；
2，”builder“这个容器的源，也是用来下载那些用来编译，打包，构建文件系统所需的Debian原生的二进制包和源码包的，所以，它必须是最新的，如果它过时的话，不用说编译，之前的”下载“都会出问题的，这是其他的机制来保证的。

I could envision more tooling for ring analysis that might want to open up a ring without any ability to do real lookups, and it doesn't seem great to push that particular wheel-reinvention on them... but I also don't have any such tools already dreamed up, much less implemented.

(Side note: it feels weird to have you of all people suggesting that monkey patching is the better solution!)

From poking at making a new ring utility (that still doesn't need to do any lookups) in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/857234, I wonder if we could get away with using a RingData here instead of a Ring proper...

*shrug* "practicality beats purity" is a lesson I try to keep in mind... 

I don't have any (other?) tools in mind either, but if we're looking for a more "pure" solution, maybe a DeadRing class that "works" but you can't do lookups on names?  We could totally use that here or other places and leave the config validation methods in the *real* Ring class.
I don't *think* I really have anything against this in this tight context in a short lived cli tool?  I definately like it better than the "do_validation=False' or whatever in the previous version...

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Add support for backing up a subcloud or a group of subclouds using dcmanager API.

The commit includes changes to API and backend dcmanager to validate the user input, create inventory and overrides file and invoke the wrapper playbook for one or multiple subclouds. The wrapper playbook, delivered in a separate commit to playbooks repo, will invoke the subcloud backup playbook and transfer backup file as needed to the system controller.

In addition, two additional attributes are added to subcloud persistent data: backup_status and backup_datetime. They are included in the dcmanager subcloud related command response.
Unit tests will be added in a separate commit.
Removed this line, as it's not needed in the final commit message.

Not sure if I agree on the group scenario. Not having the failed subclouds marked may cause the user to miss that this happened if the remainder of the operation succeeds, especially if the number of subclouds to backup is large.

Can just make one general log:
"The following subclouds are not online and/or managed and will not be backed up: ..."

For ease of debugging, I'd use subcloud names instead of subcloud ids for logging purposes.
Alarm is meant for backup failure not for prep failure.
They are mutually exclusive. Why both fields are being updated?

Forgot to add default values here, should have tested this before. Fixed it and verified the behavior by quickly adapting a unit test (will not add it to this review, since it's not included in the scope of this commit).

doc/source/node_management/openstack/con.message:
I think it might be better you use the system commands.  This way, the user would not have to log into each system to check the sysfs.

So in this case, the user could check the sriov_totalvfs value for a number that is greater than 0.

The user would first check the port associated with the configured pci-passthrough interface:

system host-if-list <host>

Then check the value of sriov_totalvfs on the port:

system host-port-show <host> <port name>

Maybe the doc folks have a stronger opinion on this, but the alternative to pointing to the wiki, would be to split the two methods explicitly in this document.  That is, the method of using a neutron port, and the method of using the pci alias.  (the wiki also requires the user to run lspci on each host -- the vendor and device id are also be able to be retrieved from the system host-port-show)
I think you'd only need the project network if using the neutron port method (SR-IOV supported), so can move this step to after 'Unlock the compute node'

You are completely right here :)
The wiki step adds the network to the vm probably only for granting external access to it (usually a mgmt net). Of course...
It was mine confusion here, will be fixing it.

Thanks for pointing it out Steve!

I don't think so.  The reason for creating the network is to be able to create a neutron direct_physical port on-top of it for use later (in the case the NIC supports SR-IOV).

In your nova boot command example for the PCI-PT in this patchset, you are specifying --network net0  .  This will just create a virtual port on the net0 network, and doesn't have anything to do with the physical device passed via the alias.  It may look funny, because usually you would have a --network <NAME> even in the case of using the pci_alias method.  But this --network <NAME> usually refers to a management network.

In fact you do need the project network on both cases, as peer the wiki [1]:
openstack network create --project ${ADMINID} --provider-network-type=vlan --provider-physical-network=${PHYSNET1} --provider-segment=500 ${PUBLICNET1}

Or am I missing something here?

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/StarlingX/Networking#Useful_Networking_Commands
You may want to say 'or the flavor created in step <X>'

.. note::

Specifying the port-id is not required if using a pci-passthrough interface which does not support SR-IOV
One minor issue, fix indentation of the note.
Try not to name the steps by their numbering as this is constantly changing.
There is still a minor issue on this line when the page is rendered, but that is being handled by Elisa here: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/docs/+/853826

Reword ?

Configure a PCI Passthrough Ethernet Interface on a host and request a PCI Passthrough Ethernet Interace for an instance at instance boot/create time.

I find this procedure confusing to follow what is being done on the platform and what is being done in OpenStack.

Shouldn't we clearly split up the steps done on platform and OpenStack.

e.g. lines 31-94, 119-135 are for the PLATFORM
     lines 97-117, 137-200 are for OpenStack

A small thing I'll note is that we don't support PCI-PT as a use case on the platform.  That is, giving a PCI-PT to a container via the SR-IOV device plugin is not supported (one could always just use the 'host-device' plugin).  Although, I do see what Greg is saying here.  To use PCI-PT with Openstack VMs, one does need to run some platform commands go get that setup.
Tried to make it clearer now. Thanks folks.

I also think that it is a little confusing to mix PCI-Passthrough and SRIOV.

There is another section/page for SRIOV  ( https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_dfe/853359/16/check/openstack-tox-docs/dfea299/docs/node_management/openstack/pci-sr-iov-ethernet-interface-devices.html )

I would
- move the PCI-Passthrough and SRIOV interfaces so they are one after another
- Change the PCI-Passthrough page to ONLY talk about PCI-Passthrough
- CHange the SRIOV page to (instead of talking only about differences with pci-passthroguh procedure) provide full procedure and steps for SRIOV case ... i know there will be a lot of duplication, but will be easier to understand.
My last patchset covered the last two items from my response.

why you set to "ldap" at bootstrap, and no OS check?

During unlock, the platform::ldap::client will be applied by include, where it takes default value for the "ldapserver_prot" parameter (which is 'ldap' for CentOS and 'ldaps' for Debian), so for Debian, it'll be 'ldaps'.
Because the following execs all run against insecure ldap (/etc/ldap/certs/openldap-cert.crt/key are not generated during bootstrap yet). So both OS should have 'ldap' for the client configuration.
This leads to the follow up that ldaps would need to be set after the cert and key are created at runtime, so after commands in class "platform::ldap::secure::config". Where is this done?

First off, apologies for the extremely late review here.

As I look through this, I have a *really* hard time understand why we're adding this complexity. The primary use case appears to be around removing resource agents when a unit is removed, (though I can't figure out the register-to-cloud action use case beyond facilitating developer test cases) but I think if that's the primary driver for this - we should just fix the problem where the user experience goes from:

1. run a
2. run b
3. run c
4. run d

to 

1. juju remove-unit unit/0

Hi Billy, thanks for your review.

This patch was heavily based on the changes of this patch[1] in charm-nova-compute. On the bug#1691998 [2] was mentioned that besides the problem of not removing from nova service catalog, it was also not removing neutron-openvswitch agents.

So the main reasons why more steps were added rather than just running `juju remove-unit` are:

1 - On charm-nova-compute there was a concern about race conditions between n-c-c (nova-cloud-controller) and n-c (nova-cloud) because of the async nature and no guaranteed order of hooks execution after the `juju remove-unit` command is executed, meaning that the n-c-c units could receive the event before the n-c unit, so the nova-compute service would still be running when the n-c-c logic is running.
I guess at the time that the same thing could happen between neutron-api and neutron-openvswitch.

2 - I've tried to keep the same pattern used on charm-nova-compute to keep the same user experience, meaning that the user probably would need to run the same commands to remove a n-c unit and/or neutron-openvswitch.

I would say that I don't see a big problem merging what disable does on pause and what enable does on resume, but I will check with my teammates. 

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute/commit/ceb8a68868ab495d16d8c1ccee7d04822fcf8d26
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-nova-compute/+bug/1691998

I think the pause and resume actions operate at the systemd service level. Whereas enable and disable work at higher level and relate to enabling and disabling  services within the cloud. So I think the enable and disable actions are fine. However the remove-from-cloud and register-to-cloud actions make less sense to me. Could you see whether unregistering agents could be done by the charm as part of a departing hook?

Thanks Dan. Probably we should try to configure only the interfaces specified in the nic templates when running this playbook

> Thanks Dan. Probably we should try to configure only the interfaces specified in the nic templates when running this playbook

+1 on changing the approach for the "safe-defaults" on error.

If we knew which interface was used to connect back to the undercloud, we should probably try to just get that specific interface back up using a default DHCP config. And only if communication back is actually not working, if the os-net-config error happened on other interfaces/bonds it would actually be better to report the error back without trying to configure defaults. 

AFAIK the safe-default on error was put in place to try to avoid a node getting isolated, an isolated node will not be able to report back an error and the deployment will keep running until timeout.

I actually believe it is because he is declaring both test classes. He can declare both if one doesn't inherit the other, or just declare the child one that will run all tests once.

nit: I prefer parenthesis for line continuation over \. Not sure if that is official in our coding guideline. But we should decide on one or the other.

Hi James,
Originally we relate prometheus-ceph-exporter to ceph-mon to get metrics.
From ceph version nautilus, ceph provides builtin metrics so we don't need prometheus-ceph-exporter any more.
The reason we need ceph version in relation is: we want to block prometheus-ceph-exporter when a ceph-mon unit with new ceph version is relating to it.
I understand this looks overkill, but we didn't find better solution to let prometheus-ceph-exporter know ceph version. 
Do you have any suggestions, please ?

unit_tests/test_lib_charm_openstack_mysq.message: This is a nice test that tests the happy path; it's probably worth for coverage, to verify the failure path.

> But it fails on testing with a message of `subprocess.CalledProcessError` not inheriting from `BaseException`, which it does. 

I ran into this recently and it was so annoying.  The reason it happens is that 'subprocess' has been mocked, and so it is a Mock() rather than BaseException().  Which is really annoying.  You an work around it by just either re-mocking the CalledProcessError using a spec, or just creating a custom exception.

I've actually was struggling with the unhappy path implementation, with something like this:

`...
    midbc.run_mysqlsh_script = mock.MagicMock()
    midbc.run_mysqlsh_script.side_effect = 
        subprocess.CalledProcessError(-1,"mysqlsh")
    with self.assertRaises(subprocess.CalledProcessError):
        midbc.restore_quorum()
`

But it fails on testing with a message of `subprocess.CalledProcessError` not inheriting from `BaseException`, which it does. 
After some research, could not found any solution that was not very hacky and I guess that's why this is not being tested on other cases.

hooks/ceph_hooks.py.message:
is there potential for the node being removed from the application to be the leader?

I'm not sure quite what we would do in this instance.

It can happen, but as far as I understand, it should not be an issue, since the hook is capable of running even when the leader itself is affected (I've run the functional tests manually to test this case).

Yes, I think it should be fine to run this hook as the leader. In fact, if we're dependent on the leader to make the change and we don't do this, then there's the distinct possibility that the mon unit wouldn't be removed from the mon cluster at all as there is no guarantee that the other units will fire the -departed hook while they retain leadership.
We need some logging here to indicate what the failure might be - this will be extremely to debug without some trace/debug.
What happens if the unit that's being removed is the leader?

config.yaml.message:
In some high memory pressure scenarios, the memory shortage would make
the high order pages hard to be allocated and also the page allocation
would go to the synchronous frequently reclaim thanks to the default gap 
between min<->low<->high is too small to wake up the kswapd (asynchronous
reclaim) earlier. The tuning proposes a mechanism to fine-tune the sysctl
memory parameters (watermark_scale_factor) at runtime to improve the 
situation.

Sorry, the sentence can be changed to make it clear:

  "memory parameters (watermark_scale_factor) at runtime to improve the"
=>"memory parameters (watermark gap to 1GB) at runtime to improve the"

However, in the Ubuntu kernel, the watermark_scale_factor function exists only
from v4.15(Bionic). The tuning cannot be used before the Bionic kernel. In
fact, the watermark_scale_factor patch is merged in v4.6-rc1.

795ae7a0de6b mm: scale kswapd watermarks in proportion to memory

The root cause of the bug, IIUC, is that when the proxy selects a controller class to handle an object request it uses the result of swift.proxy.controllers.base.get_container_info() which does have the correct storage policy index even when the container status is 404. However, when the chosen controller handles the object request it selects the policy (again!) using swift.proxy.controllers.base.Controller.container_info() which was scrubbing the policy index for status 404.

(Aside: This could probably have been avoided altogether by instantiating ObjectController instances with the policy for which they were selected (AFAICT we use an instance per request), rather than digging out the policy index multiple times and passing it around the call hierarchy.)

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: hm, can we still use dev_info['parent'] for libvirt < 7.7 or that code path never worked?

Well, the bug was due to a stupid copy/paste, the logic was wrong. See what we were doing before this change :
- look at all the instances and give me all the mdev UUIDs each instance has in the XML
- verify whether the related mdev exists in sysfs for this UUID
- well, if not, then we don't have a mdev but we know we should recreate it.

Then, what we do ? We ask libvirt to get the mdev information (L1076). But heh, the mdev is not existing ! 

To answer your question, _get_mediated_device_information() returns you a dict for the mdev, where *indeed* we have a key named "parent", even before libvirt 7.7.

But, see, given the mdev doesn't exist, we couldn't get the parent :) 

Fortunately, after libvirt 7.7, now the parent name is *also* in the mdev name, so we can get it, without asking libvirt (or Placement).
What we could do for libvirt <7.7 is to ask Placement which RP is getting an allocation for this mdev, and that's what someone tried to work on with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/810220 but I think that's simplier to no longer accept to recreate mdevs if libvirt <7.7 and just wait for libvirt to provide us what we need.

does the parent from the libvirt devname suffix the same as the parent we get via cfgdev.parent from libvirt? If yes then I don't see why we need to have two ways to read that parent info. The cfgdev.parent way seems the more stable one so I would like to use that.

We can't obtain anything from libvirt as the mdev no longer exists. What we only have is the mdev UUID in the guest domain XML.

... // later.

Oh, shit, I'm *again* wrong : the above can't work : we don't have a libvirt name stored in the instance domain XML but just a regular UUID4 corresponding to the mdev UUID.

Shit, what we then only need for this code is to drop the call to mdev_name2parent() as it won't never be useful in recreate.

unnecessary. test_notification is called synchronously from API. A user understands the error immediately, and it is not so good to keep waiting.
On the other hand, send_notification is called asynchronously.

Just a question,
This send_notification() method is called as async_call, so I am worried that the following reverse order may occur.

1. Send notify(STARTING)         => Connection/Send Failed, and Retry
2. Send notify(PROCESSING)       => Success
3. Send notify(STARTING) (Retry) => Success

I think it will be fine if it doesn't happen or if there is no problem even if it happens.

Thanks for your answer.
The reverse notification order can happen, so the receiver should care order by looking data in the notification (e.g. creation time). I understand.
It may happen. Note that there is not the guarantee of the arrival order originally even if STARTING is sent first. So I think the receipt side should care originally.

ironic/drivers/modules/snmp.py.message: I'm curious why did you drop the docs here for the other statuses? Am I missing something? (throughout)

Looking at other (existing) drivers, they did not have as detailed docs on the various statuses. I figured for readability/brevity, it was reasonable to drop the extra detail.

In particular, the '[...more options follow]' statement was already used in other drivers for similar purposes.

For each of our new drivers, we do give links to the MIBs for reference (e.g., http://support.raritan.com/px2/version-2.4.1/mibs/pdu2-mib-020400-39592.txt for the Raritan driver). That seemed a reasonable replacement.

I can restore the extended comments if wanted by app rovers. I was mostly trying to match the existing style seen in other comments for other drivers.

reference/runtimes/2023.1.rst.message:
As I mentioned on IRC, it seems weird to me to put CS9 in here when we're not gating on it, and it can easily break for months at a time where we may not be able to run our periodic jobs based on it.

If we're getting 3.9 from Debian 11, is that not good enough?
done, added it in Best Effort list.

AFAIK, this is the first "best effort" statement we've had in the tested runtimes list, so I think it's important to be clear here.  When we say "These may not be part of integrated testing", do we mean that the TC is not giving permission for using these in integrated testing (i.e., "must not be part of integrated testing") or that there's no guarantee that these will be used in integrated testing (though we aren't prohibiting it either)?.  "Best effort" sort of implies the former, but considering the second conjunct, "may be tested periodically only", a reasonable interpretation is that we are saying that what "best effort" means for the TC is that only periodic testing is allowed (in order to optimize testing resource consumption, for example).

We can't assume that everyone knows what "best effort" means because it has different meanings in different contexts.  In some countries, when you say "best effort" it's taken to mean that you will do everything possible to accomplish something, whereas in others it simply means that you'll do what you can within reason (but you're not going to drop everything else to fix this particular issue).

The TC can't/shouldn't really tell projects *not* to test something, so I think it's the latter: OpenStack changes are not necessarily tested on CentOS Stream, though we'll attempt to find and fix bugs post-merge through periodic CentOS Stream testing where possible. Because CentOS Stream is essentially a rolling development distribution, we're not recommending it for production deployment of OpenStack, just trying to use it in order to identify problems which may arise when running OpenStack on RHEL (since we have no direct way to run tests on RHEL).

Yes, this document define what minimum we should test for this particular release and no limit on maximum testing, for example any project/group can test N number of distro in their gate.

In this 'Best effort' and 'may not be part of integrated testing' means that we do not need to test centos stream as mandatory minimum testing requirement defined in this document but you can test it like you may be testing any other distro than what we have in this document. TC does not restrict the testing.

And as we stopped testing centos stream in gate and added jobs in periodic pipeline, ''may not be part of integrated testing'' statement telling reality to know how much testing we do as minimum for this.

Yeah, I think this is saying both "the TC is not going to require stream in the gate" and "we are not going to consider working-on-stream to be a requirement for this release." That doesn't mean it's not tested anywhere, or that you *can't* test on it. The "may not" there is the "this may not work" form and not the "your mom says you MAY NOT play outside" form.

I think "best effort" here means "we know redhat-based distros are important, so we're going to run periodics on this, but otherwise we would have just ignored this distro."

The implication is that the choice of nodejs version is "based on the available and supported versions in either our LTS/stable distros or some external source" but with no indication on which one of those informed the current choice to go with the external source instead of the distros.

This was updated in response to my comments on IRC, but I'm not sure it accurately reflects reality yet. The LTS distro packages are playing no part in this at all. I wouldn't refer to them here.

Instead, we are making a pragmatic choice based on nodejs support timeframes and the availability of third party packaging for popular distros.

Well, nodejs 12 is what's available and supported in our LTS stable distributions (Ubuntu 22.04 and Debian 11 in this case). It's more a question of whether you mean "supported" by distros or "supported" by Nodesource. While I don't disagree with the choice, it would be good to clarify what "either/or" means in this case and which of them is prioritized.

I am not sure what is unclear here. What I mean here and these statement convey is that the mentioned below nodejs version is the target to be tested in this cycle which is based on availability/support in LTS distro or external source, if it is available in LTS distro then pick form there otherwise external source. there is no priority thing here as we are mentioning the nodejs exact version to target.

It is both actually, and that is why I mentioned the nodejs release page as ref here. First we can look for the LTS version and if that has long term support then it is all good otherwise look for the latest nodejs version and its source.

I think the sentence as currently stating is misleading.  The function of the paragraph at lines 38-39 is to say why we are targeting 1.6, and if it's not available in any of the pti-linux-distros packages now, then that can't be a reason for picking 1.6.  Basically, we are picking 1.6 even though it is *not* available in the LTS distros because of a judgement that there are sufficient reliable third-party packages that *can* be used by the pti-linux-distros mentioned at the top of this page.  I think we should be clear about this.

I think we also need to address Jeremy's point about what we are going to do if 1.6 packages do become available in the pti-linux-distros ... are we going to prefer using the "official" distro packages over the third-party ones we are planning to use now, will we stick with the third-party packages, or do whatever's easiest?
looks fine to me. We can also migrate to nodejs18 in the 2023.1 release as nodejs18 is the current LTS version. Let me discuss it in the weekly horizon meeting then I will update the same here.
Hi gmann, The horizon team decided to migrate it to nodejs18, the current LTS version in the next release.
perfect. let me update that in follow up patch. If I end up repining it then I will update this too.

networking_generic_switch/devices/netmik.message:
Hmm, Interesting!

Well, I don't think any other driver handles it in NGS, but other drivers do kind of handle it or submit the change into the overall SDN system. Or you can set it such that the ISL is open to all vlans in some switches. Granted, not all switches support that.

I would honestly just suggest you take the path of east resistance, but also enable it to be disabled. In other words, I would allow for the inter-switch links to be able to be defined, and the driver could update, if enabled to do so. That would help walk the balance of having a fully featured environment versus network admins that don't want new vlans to appear on interswitch links.
So I have decided to manage the ISL links out of band of this driver, as part of a script that creates the external network in openstack. So I am happy this is feature complete for now 😄

So, this is the standard way that the pluribus switches would be configured, the fabric auto configures vxlan tunnels between the switches, and ensures vlans are delivered correctly to each of the leaf switches. I believe this would be the way everyone would use it.

One issue im still thinking about is how to manage some of the additional vlan trunking and configuration, although im not sure if its out of scope for the generic switch plugin. 

For example, if your running with clustering over l2, the vlan needs to be allowed across the inter-switch link, which as far as i can see, no other driver handles. So should that be handled out of band, with this plugin only taking responsibility for ports managed by neutron?

openstack/resource.py.message:
Looking at this, I suspect the author was trying to do [1] and indeed after playing around with it locally it looks like should work:

  >>> from urllib.parse import urljoin, urlparse
  >>> url = 'http://example.com/foo/bar?a=text&q2=text2&q3=text3&q2=text4'
  >>> urljoin(url, urlparse(url).path)
  'http://example.com/foo/bar'

So I wonder why this is not working...

[1] https://stackoverflow.com/a/32214777

As you nicely described in patchset9, it works fine for absolute paths, starting with a leading /. It fails for relatives path, which are missing that:
>>> next_link="foo/bar"
>>> urljoin(next_link, urlparse(next_link).path)
'foo/foo/bar'
>>> next_link="/foo/bar"
>>> urljoin(next_link, urlparse(next_link).path)
'/foo/bar'

The method proposed by us in the original patch gives the correct answer in both cases:

>>> next_link="/foo/bar"
>>> parts = urlparse(next_link)
>>> noquery = (parts.scheme, parts.netloc,parts.path, parts.params, '', parts.fragment)
>>> urlunparse(noquery)
'/foo/bar'
>>> next_link="foo/bar"
>>> parts = urlparse(next_link)
>>> noquery = (parts.scheme, parts.netloc,parts.path, parts.params, '', parts.fragment)
>>> urlunparse(noquery)
'foo/bar'
>>> next_link = 'http://example.com/foo/bar?a=text&q2=text2&q3=text3&q2=text4'
>>> parts = urlparse(next_link)
>>> noquery = (parts.scheme, parts.netloc,parts.path, parts.params, '', parts.fragment)
>>> urlunparse(noquery)
'http://example.com/foo/bar'

Not removing the leading / for glance would solve the issue for this special case. I just wonder if it was not better to correct that function and make it work for both cases.

> As you nicely described in patchset9, it works fine for absolute paths, starting with a leading /.

I think we might be mixing up terminology here. An absolute path in a Linux context is one that starts *with* a leading forward slash. However, an absolute URL is one that starts *without* a leading forward slash: instead, it starts with the (optional) scheme, the hostname, and (optional) the port. Consider this very URL. First, an absolute URL:

  review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/853656/

Now a relative URL:

  /c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/853656/

You need the leading slash to distinguish these. Consider the following perfectly legitimate URL:

  example.com/openstack.org/data/image.png

A "relative" URL without the leading slash would be indistinguishable from an absolute URL:

  openstack.org/data/image.png

As such, I don't think relative URLs without a leading slash are valid, at least not for our use cases here.

> It fails for relatives path, which are missing that:
> >>> next_link="foo/bar"
> >>> urljoin(next_link, urlparse(next_link).path)
> 'foo/foo/bar'
> >>> next_link="/foo/bar"
> >>> urljoin(next_link, urlparse(next_link).path)
> '/foo/bar'

As above, I don't think these are valid. Almost as importantly though, does anything actually return this style of URL? Glance certainly doesn't...

> The method proposed by us in the original patch gives the correct answer in both cases:
> 
> >>> next_link="/foo/bar"
> >>> parts = urlparse(next_link)
> >>> noquery = (parts.scheme, parts.netloc,parts.path, parts.params, '', parts.fragment)
> >>> urlunparse(noquery)
> '/foo/bar'
> >>> next_link="foo/bar"
> >>> parts = urlparse(next_link)
> >>> noquery = (parts.scheme, parts.netloc,parts.path, parts.params, '', parts.fragment)
> >>> urlunparse(noquery)
> 'foo/bar'
> >>> next_link = 'http://example.com/foo/bar?a=text&q2=text2&q3=text3&q2=text4'
> >>> parts = urlparse(next_link)
> >>> noquery = (parts.scheme, parts.netloc,parts.path, parts.params, '', parts.fragment)
> >>> urlunparse(noquery)
> 'http://example.com/foo/bar'
> 
> Not removing the leading / for glance would solve the issue for this special case. I just wonder if it was not better to correct that function and make it work for both cases.

Given these aren't valid (IMO), I don't think we should make the code more complicated to address them. If you insist then we can but there is value in keeping things simple (KISS principle)
Ack. +1 for the KISS principle (involving minimal changes).

Broadly this seems like the logical thing to do; -1 just for visibility of comments on dib testing here:

One thing I'd like to see covered as a work-item is decoupling dib testing from nodepool too.  Currently dib image build+boot testing is based on having nodepool-builder run the build and nodepool-launcher upload it to a devstack-based test environment.

The broadness of this testing has been of mutual benefit to both sides of the dib/nodepool equation; although the trade-off is that it is slow, and there is some tension between the projects as to "why is my <dib|nodepool> change blocked on <nodepool|dib>" (usually this is a real problem, but not always).

With the validation steps covered in here, we can set up something that we test the zuul built images before making them live; but I don't think this is appropriate for speculative testing of the more generic image changes that come into dib.  

What I think dib wants to keep is the end-to-end build+boot cloud test.  Because this has also traditionally been a openstacksdk and glean (i.e. metadata) proxy test, it seems worth nothing that we think keeping the "push to a devstack" part of the testing is useful (rather than say, just booting in a qemu instance by hand, or using virt-manager or something)?

The easiest path is thus, I guess, to keep the extant environment, but to excise nodepool from the dib boot tests; call dib directly in the tests to produce the images (remove nodepool-builder) and upload/boot the images directly (remove nodepool-launcher) rather than having nodepool do it.  I'd call this a moderate amount of work, as we're replicating a lot of things nodepool handles for us like networking setup etc.  That could happen more or less asynchronously, but would need to be done before retirement of nodepool.

The other option would be to integrate zuul's new image handling into this testing, in the same way nodepool does now; basically converting dib testing to brings up a zuul to talk to devstack and use that to build, push and boot the test images.  This does have the benefit of being a very good test, but the downside of sounding very complicated.

so; tldr

- dibs boot testing of common platforms builds and pushes into a devstack cloud.
- propose we agree that this is still quite useful given what it's trying to verify (that changes boot and communicate in a openstack cloud).
- note that nodepool needs to be excised from this testing
- decide if we replace that in dib with a bespoke build/upload step, or try to setup a zuul environment to mostly replicate the complete end-to-end testing that happens with nodepool.
Thanks, the proposal looks really good to me.

Agree -- my inclination is toward the "bespoke build/upload" option.  Mostly because a lot of the "build an image with dib" parts of this will be self-testing in jobs, so a full Zuul system with the jobs to do that would be redundant (and as you say complicated).  Whereas extracting just the steps to build and upload an image to devstack into a python script localizes what we want to test better.  I'll update the spec to mention that.
Done

Yeah it would... I've been thinking about that and it just seems messy though because we still want images to be "global".

I mean, we could totally have a repo where we have "image" stanzas like below.  Let's use opendev as an example.  We could have "opendev/images" with that configuration in it.  And then we could include opendev/images in every tenant (but with 'include: [image]' in most tenants, and only include jobs, etc, in the "opendev" tenant).  Then every tenant gets access to those images.  If a tenant has extra "image" definitions, it gets access to those extra images as well.  For example, let's say we have an "openstack/images" repo where we make special devstack images for openstack.  So far so good.

So what if we have:

opendev/images: has a "debian-unstable" image
openstack/images: has a "devstack" image
zuul/images: decides to define its own "devstack" image

Since our image names are global, we have a name conflict and it's a bit tricky to resolve because the actual image exists outside of the context of a tenant (I'm taking it for granted we don't want to build/upload copies of images for each tenant).

Maybe what we could do is, internally, we go ahead and use the canonical name.  So in ZooKeeper, we store image information at:

/zuul/images/opendev.org%2fopendev%fimages%2fdebian-unstable/...

And then when we go to run a job, we use the configuration objects in that tenant to resolve the label down to an image, and whatever repo defines that devstack image we use the full canonical image name.  So if the job says to use the "devstack" label and the "devstack" label says to use the "devstack" image, if that job is running in the openstack tenant, it's going to get the "opendev.org/openstack/images/devstack" and if a job runs in the zuul tenant, it's going to get "opendev.org/zuul/images/devstack".  Which is probably what each expects.

Here few thoughts while thinking about our use cases.

Our users should not have/need knowledge about the instnace flavors that are used/available in the backend. Having the possibility to define virtual flavors could achieve that. 

Many of our labels are specified by our projects to run in specific regions aka providers. It could be tedious to have labels and provider/pool attachments distributed. I think it might make sense to also allow to specify the pools that should serve a label directly on the label. In order to achieve that we'd need to allow specifying the image, virtual flavor (I think this would likely be required for this use case) and possibly further information on the label stanza.

We also need to restrict the available flavors that are available to tenants. This could also achieved by defining virtual labels and somehow restrict defining them via the tenant config to certain repos via the include/exclude of object types in the tenant config. In order to facilitate the config it might make sense to define default includes/excludes on a tenant (e.g. exclude by default certain nodepool object types) and enable them specifically on certain repos that are intended to hold nodepool config.

I feel like I don't have enough information from this comment to fully understand what you want.  I think most of the confusion comes from your use of the word "users" and where you want to draw the line on what they know and don't know.

So far, this spec isn't designed to really change any of that.  Right now, in order to update the nodepool configuration, you need to know everything about the clouds nodepool is using.  A Zuul user doesn't need to know that -- their only interface with nodepool is the "label" concept.  The idea is that the Zuul/Nodepool system operator tells them what labels are available.  (If some or all of the Zuul users also happen to understand the clouds and the nodepool configuration, that's fine of course, but it's not necessary.)

Fundamentally, the idea is that a Zuul user doesn't have to know anything more about the test resource configuration than a label.  That's the unit of abstraction.

With this spec, nothing about that has to change -- all of these are new configuration objects, and they can be restricted to only be loaded from certain repos.  So users can still use abstract/opaque labels to specify what resources they want, and the people responsible for the current nodepool configuration can still be responsible for it by maintaining the repos with these new configuration objects in them.

Having said all that, of course we can change things, but I think in order to do that, we should start from a common point and work from there.  Given that the current system is designed to be mantained by people who know all the details of the clouds and provide labels to end users, what do you want to change starting from that point?

Maybe we could define some specific use cases.

Regarding the last point -- it is already the case that any Zuul configuration object can be included or excluded from any repo, and tenants can specify default sets for include/exclude (and in fact, you can make any arbitrary grouping of projects with a given include/exclude set).  That would certainly be true for every new configuration object as well, so anything included in this spec.  That is absolutely the basis for access control for all of this.

I chatted with Tobias about this some, and I think this is the gist of it: we can take this opportunity to make the configuration more user accessible.  The main new use case is: a tenant administrator (ie, a power user who is not responsible for the entire system, only the content within their tenant) should be able to manage the lifecycle of a diskimage without help from the system administrator.  This spec was already anticipating that for maintaining the jobs that build images, but image lifecycle also includes adding and deleting images, so users will need to be able to attach them to providers (if the admin allows it).

Another point Tobias raised: being able to abstract flavors will make label management across multiple clouds much easier and will remove a lot of boilerplate configuration.

I think the next version will address these points.
It would also be great to have config-drive (we need to enable this on every onprem image) also as a global flag on the openstack provider or pool. But I think that's useful independent of this spec.
Yeah, I think we could add a default flag for that.

We have tenants with ~100 images that are very hard to switch as a big bang. I think we'd need a more fine grained way of switching on a label-by-label basis.

Maybe we could do that by placing node-requests for known labels in /zuul/node-requests and unknown labels in /nodepool until the tenant is marked fully migrated which would then also enable e.g. label validation in job config.

Why does the number of images affect whether a tenant switches or not?  You can have all the images ready to go before switching the tenant over (because the image builds can be done before handling any node requests).  And in general, you can switch a smaller tenant over first to verify that node requests are working correctly.

The label validation is needed for more than just the job config, it's also needed for provider config, etc.  Even today, it's a Nodepool config error for a provider to have a label entry for a label that doesn't exist.  So if we made the presence of a label in a tenant be an indication of whether we use old or new requests, we would need to extend that to the pool configuration as well.  So basically, to turn on a label in a tenant, you would have to add both the "label" object and also add that label to a pool.

Given that it's anticipated that many label and pool definitions would be kept in a central repo that is added to multiple tenants, this behavior (even just the "label" behavior alone) really means that under your proposal, switching to the new system would be label-by-label but for all tenants at once, unless you combined the two, so that there was a tri-state tenant flag:

1) Old requests only
2) New requests for known labels, otherwise old requests
3) New requests only (validation enabled)

Then you could start with all tenants at #1, then switch a small tenant to #2 and add some labels, then switch a large tenant to #2 and add more labels until they are all using new requests, then switch all tenants to #2 then #3.

Is that what you had in mind?

Do we have to list all images here or only when we want to override some image config on the provider level?

I'm asking since the label already specifies the associated image. If we just need this for overriding image attributes we should maybe call this "image-overrides" instead.

This is the same as the "images" attribute on the "section" object, that way a tenant can (if permitted) configure cloud/section-specific attributes of tenant-specific images.  In other words, a section might have image "A" and a provider might add image "B" to that, so that ultimately both A and B are available.

I don't think I specified what should happen if we have "A" on both.  That should probably be an error?  Because we probably don't want a provider overriding something set on a section?

With that in mind, I think I'd prefer to keep it as "images", but if we want to change it, I think it should be in both places.
Nit: are built

For case #2 I don't think it is currently possible to enqueue a build for a single job. Instead we have to enqueue a trigger event which will build all matching jobs. Will we update the enqueue tooling to enable us to enqueue a single build job as described for the image build trigger below? I think this will be important for manually triggered builds as we often don't want to build the world due to contention of resources when a single image needs updating.
I think this comment is sufficient. I just wanted to make sure it was on your radar before we committed to something that may have been clunky from a manual management perspective.

I don't think we'd specify a particular job, but we would specify a particular image or set of images.  See the paragraph from lines 121-127 for a description of the new image attribute for jobs that we would expect the pipeline to match.  I think what's missing is a description of the fact that the triggering image attribute described in lines 112-119 would carry over to the enqueued item and be used to match the jobs.  With a new attribute on the queue item, that's conceptually compatible with direct enqueueing an item.  Maybe this comment is enough to clarify that, or I can add a few more sentences to that effect.

One advantage of the current system compared to this proposed system is that we can keep a copy of our images long term in local build storage. At times this is also a disadvantage when we can't delete images and they build up and fill the builder disk.

With artifact uploads in opendev I believe we have a 30 day expiry. We may need to think about variable expiries for different object types like images.

I don't think this is really a problem. More of a point to consider as this rolls out.

Yeah, I think this actually adds flexibility.  To continue the opendev example, we don't have to use our existing log storage locations, we can set up new locations with different retention periods (and we may prefer to use a subset of the places we use for log storage).
Ack

Would such job definitions be limited to trusted config repos, or otherwise controlled via ACL in order to prevent arbitrary users of the system from adding images? And would the system enforce uniqueness for the image-build-name parameter (at least for non-abstract jobs)? This may be related to the tenant discussion farther down, though I'm also concerned with the potential for limiting who has permission to do this within a given tenant.

The jobs could be defined anywhere jobs are normally defined -- but they won't do anything special like upload images unless they are attached to an image building pipeline (which has certain triggers and reporters which are able to be restricted -- see my conversation with Clark).  So the way you say "this tenant can or can not add images" is to supply or allow that kind of pipeline in the tenant.

The image name is... let's call it... "implicitly unique".  Because behind the scenes, Zuul will map that image name to an "image" stanza and the image stanza will always internally use a fully qualified name including the repo where it is defined.  So "debian-unstable" in opendev really means something like "(opendev.org/opendev/images, debian-unstable)".  That's described in lines 375-388).  So a single tenant can only have one "debian-unstable" image and Zuul will enforce that uniqueness in the usual way.  But "debian-unstable" in two different tenants might mean the same image, or they might not, depending on whether the debian-unstable image stanza is literally in the same repo or in a different one.

For opendev, we will almost certainly only have one definition and share it among all the tenants.  That mimics our current behavior.

Currently image builds are well spread out in OpenDev which is nice because it avoids overwhelming the storage systems in clouds when the image build completes and we shift to uploading the images. Shifting to triggering all the image builds at midnight (or relatively close using jitter) may result in undesireable thundering herds.
Good point, and definitely something that OpenDev should plan to do to avoid this problem.
We can use a Zuul semaphore to limit the number of concurrent builds.

While I don't think it's a reason to avoid this design, it's worth considering that these are potentially very large files and we would now be copying them back and forth over the network multiple times (as opposed to the current model where they're uploaded directly from local storage). Not only does this imply a potentially significant increase in bandwidth usage, but also provides additional opportunities for network and service issues adversely impacting those long-running file transfers, degrading the stability of the image upload.
Yes, compared to the current system, this may add 2 transfers for an image, if a given zuul-launcher has access to all providers.  If it is scoped to fewer providers, more transfers may be needed.
This is a useful feature though, which may mitigate some of my points above.

This trigger event will identify the specific build of an image right? Otherwise we might not be verifying the correct build of an image.

Additionally this may be necessary to manually trigger a reupload of an image. For example if an upload was corrupted in the target cloud we might need to trigger a delete for a specific cloud image and then reupload it.
Ack

Yes, we'll include that info on the trigger event and queue item as well so that the node request will use exactly that build (which is otherwise not yet in service).

I agree we should handle the delete use-case.  I think we can handle it with manual commands similar to how we do now -- if we have a command to delete the upload from the provider and remove the image id from the path described at line 237 then this cycle can restart.
Does this imply the local launcher copy of the image is ephemeral and may be deleted aggressively? I think that may be a good idea since the images can grow to be quite large.
Yes, I envision that it would delete its local copy as soon as it has performed all the uploads that it can.
Ack

I worry that this sort of access control isn't sufficient. In the past tenants have largely been able to self manage pipelines, but that didn't have an impact of behind the scenes cloud resources. We may need to indicate if a tenant is allowed to build images in the zuul tenant config.

The problem is that making images that boot in the various clouds is actually quite difficult. We also have to think about uploaded image quotas. I'm concerned that allowing this broadly will produce two problems:

 1) Users thinking clouds don't work because they don't understand how to configure networking on boot. Or otherwise making assumptions like everything is kvm (when xen is possible).
 2) Users adding images that they never remove when they are no longer needed. OpenDev has a difficult enough time pruning images already and I know people will leave the 10 year old ubuntu image around even though it shouldn't be used and likely isn't used. This will impact the clouds negatively through unnecessary resource consumption.
 
I like the idea of making this configurable and then we can think about this on a tenant by tenant basis at least.

That makes sense.  We have generally assumed quite a large range of permitted actions from config repos, but already have an `allowed-triggers` tenant config option to restrict what pipelines can do.  Since this is proposed as an enhancement to the `zuul` trigger, that alone isn't sufficient; we may need to augment that with something like `allowed-zuul-events` or maybe just a boolean `allow-image-builds`.  With that, we can prevent people from adding image builds to pipelines in certain tenants.

Having said that, I personally think this would be a boon even for opendev to allow tenants to manage their own images.  Most of opendev's images should be common and built in the opendev tenant, but I could see the utility of tenant-specific images.

Plus with the ability to use job inheritance, we could tune our caching situation a bit better (eg, devstack images are built from a child job that just caches some more blobs).
I agree the use case should be supported.  I'm on board with adding allow-image-builds as a tenant config option.
Per matrix it sounds like we are all on baord with making this configurable. I don't think that needs a full respin as we appear to be in agreement.

I don't know if this is possible, but if you can download a snapshotted image after taking the snapshot then upload it to typical cloud storage the rest of the previously described process could continue to be used.
Ack
That might be possible in some environments; if it's supported universally, that sounds like it would be a good implementation.

Good point. At least from the OpenDev perspective, the only behavior change here would be that suddenly Zuul might agree to run jobs which were previously not possible (like mixing node labels we currently offer from mutually exclusive providers, i.e. x86 and arm64, or in other deployments it might mean the ability for mixing labels tied to different node drivers entirely).

It seems like this is something which should probably be allowed or denied within the nodeset (or potentially by the consuming jobs), since some jobs may rely heavily on local connectivity between nodes.
Yep, so it should be a possible enhancement that is backwards compatible with current behaviors.

I think at least in the initial implementation we would expect that if a provider can supply multiple labels within a nodeset, we would have it fulfill as many as possible, and only yield nodes to other providers which cannot fulfill them.  That would make the system work as it does today transparently.

There is another goal that might be good to add which is treating requests in a more queue like fashion. Basically we know who is next in line for node type foo and instead of assigning a specific instance boot to that request we can just hand the next successful but to the next item in the queue.

This gets a little tricky when you have to deal with provider constraints for locality but I think for a lot of jobs this would make users experience a bit more predictable and expected.

I can think of some ways to do that, but so far, they are all very complex and involve having two queues (one queue with the nodeset requests then a second for individual or locality-bound groups of nodes).

If we do want to set this as a goal, I think the existing algorithm laid out below would need to be replaced and it would be a significant revision of this spec.

Personally, I'm not sure the benefits are going to be worth the complexity, since even the current system mostly starts jobs in the order you expect (and most of the differences are due to different node types or providers).  But I'm open to the revision if people feel this is important.  It would be harder to implement later.

I mostly wanted to call that out as addressing the confusion users have when they see jobs start ahead of theirs for the same node type would be nice. If we are going to address that this seems like a good opportunity for it.

That said I agree it is a relatively minor thing and something that we can educate users about rather than building more complexity into the tool. I'm good with keeping the old node request assignment behavior instead.

I think this may be at odds with my earlier suggestion of limiting which tenants can define images. Maybe we need a new privileged type of repo? In particular I do not see us wanting to allow any of our tenants in OpenDev to be able to create random images without OpenDev's review. There are too many gotchas about image format types and how to boot with networking for all the various clouds to allow people to have at it on their own. On top of that images in a cloud represent resource utilization that we'll want to manage.
Ack

I don't think it's at odds.  As described above, we can add an option to the tenant config to enable/disable building images.  With that in mind, this just describes a repo with all the image definitions and in opendev's case, we would put them all in that repo and then add that to all the tenants.  Only the opendev tenant would actually build them.

Having said that, and just as a parenthetical aside that doesn't really affect this spec, I do think we should consider allowing tenant-specific builds.  I don't think there's much harm in that if we provide good base image build jobs.  I only mention this to suggest keeping an open mind for what we might do with opendev.  We'll definitely support the current "only the admins touch images" approach.  But we don't have to be limited to it if we choose.

An example of the new connection details showing how we interface with external auth info like a clouds.yaml and various regions might be helpful. Though I suspect that is largely a mechanical mapping.

Yes, I think it's pretty mechanical -- I think it would look sort of like zuul's existing connections with the necessary fields from nodepool mapped in.  So zuul.conf would look like:
```
[connection rackspace]
driver=openstack
cloud=rax
```
Ack
Are we thinking other information would replace or override/supplement the default in the image definition in the case where both define this info?

Reproducing the relevant lines:

469 * ``image`` stanza                                                                              
470 * ``flavor`` stanza
471 * ``label`` stanza
472 * ``section`` stanza (top level)
473 * ``image`` within ``section``
474 * ``flavor`` within ``section``
475 * ``provider`` stanza (top level)
476 * ``label`` within ``provider``

Currently, given X images and Y providers, we set that flag X*Y times.  With this proposal, we could do the same by setting it using line 473.  Or we could set it only once per image (X times) by setting it using line 469.  Or we could set it once per provider (Y times) by setting it using line 475.  Or we could set it once per cloud (let's call that O(1) time) by setting using line 472 and section inheritance.
ok, thanks! Missed that bit about top-level overrides.

Yes both override and supplement.  The order of precedence is in lines 469-576.

That addresses one of Tobias's pet peeves about having to say "config-drive: true" everywhere.  :)

Just wondering how this solves the issue of having to define/override it for every image? Can the image name be a regex and match multiple images? Otherwise it would just be defined in a different location (image stanza vs. image in section).
I think we should do that similar to how we only install all the extra ansible stuff in the executor image.
Ack
That's the way I'm leaning too.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: During further testing done in an independent set of clusters, we found that 'shared' is not appropriate. After investigation, setting the flag 'z' on the volume bind mount is what resulted in permission being granted, and was verified across at least two independent clusters by two separate developers.
I'd used "shared,z" in order to converge with the other mounts of that specific location.

May be replaced by another one: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/856535

Though I didn't set ":ro,z" - we can discuss that on due time if you want.

So based on further discussion on IRC with Takashi and others, it seems there might be an issue further up the chain that needs to be resolved. We're tracking this at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2122656 and I will either abandon or adjust this patch once we have a better understanding about what the solution should actually be. Thanks to everyone so far for the comments and discussion.

We shouldn't relabel that location. The right thing to do here is to grab the actual denials.
Note that a specific label is set in tripleo-heat-templates[1], and we should really stick to it.
There is an open bug at Red Hat about inconsistencies with the label for that location here[2] - we really should avoid using "z".

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/621425b2551891b1c68e42507dce4096a8e10174/deployment/nova/nova-migration-target-container-puppet.yaml#L160
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2122656

I'm fine with the 'shared' volume mount method if that's what everything else is going to use. I'm happy to abandon this one in favour of your other change per IRC discussion. Thanks for looking at this!

deployment/ceilometer/ceilometer-agent-c.message: adding z triggers relabeling these files by conainer_files_t, which looks inappropriate. We need to understand how the access is denied and find out what is the appropriate way to fix it (I assume there are selinux denials logged ?)

if it works with ro, let's use ro, it's more safe when rw.

And as nova-migration-target already uses ,z magic, that should not break things by changing the context

So I switched from ro to shared and seeing things worked, but upon further testing that didn't appear to be enough (which is why this is set to shared currently; the patch switching this to ro is because that's what the original state was until about a week or two ago).

I believe this is just reading the socket in order to poll/request from libvirt for metadata purposes. I don't think a write interface is required, which is why I ended up going back to ro. Looking at the nova yaml files is why I originally swapped to shared to align. Seems as if the 'z' flag was the more important component here. If we think it makes the most sense to align to 'shared,z' then I'm also fine with that.

after a quick check, that location is mounted with different flags in different services:
deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml:                  - /var/run/libvirt:/var/run/libvirt:shared
deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml:                  - /var/run/libvirt:/var/run/libvirt:shared
deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml:                      - /var/run/libvirt:/var/run/libvirt:shared
deployment/nova/nova-migration-target-container-puppet.yaml:                  - /var/run/libvirt:/var/run/libvirt:shared,z


According to the doc about bind-mount, shared has this feature:
Sub-mounts of the original mount are exposed to replica mounts, and sub-mounts of replica mounts are also propagated to the original mount.

I'm not sure is we really need the "shared" flag.

That said, I'm wondering why "ro" if you're trying to write in the socket? Maybe we can use the same flags as the nova-migration-target-container-puppet: shared,z

At least, it would make sure we're not doing anything weird.
(I'm surprised the nova-libvirt-container-puppet doesn't have the "z"..... might be a concern, but that's another story)

Takashi, my understanding was that 'Z' would cause relabeling, but that 'z' (lowercase) was just to allow multiple mounts of SElinux controlled locations? If 'z' is not appropriate, then do you have a suggestion or prior art (example) that I could follow on how to adjust this?

Cedric, as this seems to be a polling/read-only location, I believe keeping 'ro' (and since that's what it originally was) is appropriate here, but maybe someone from Nova team can provide more context?

Right now this basically blocks the ability to do autoscaling via CPU metrics, which is a documentation task I'm working on, and I'd like to get this driven forward if at all possible.

We're tracking this work at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2103969 and the errors posted look like this:

type=AVC msg=audit(1661320143.727:562520): avc:  denied  { write } for  pid=669402 comm="ceilometer-poll" name="virtqemud-sock-ro" dev="tmpfs" ino=93846 scontext=system_u:system_r:container_t:s0:c526,c1012 tcontext=system_u:object_r:virt_var_run_t:s0 tclass=sock_file permissive=0

If there is a better way to handle this that reduces scope to that required, I'm happy to adjust.

setup.cfg.message: should we remove this as well?

This is like what we have for cinder stable/yoga: https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/stable/yoga/setup.cfg

The requirement to run unit tests in py 3.7 ended in Victoria:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html

... but we can claim by inference that if the code works in py36 and py38, it must also work in py37.

We could run py37 tests in the gate (probably using the yoga upper-constraints?), but if we decide to, let's make it a separate patch.

etc/proxy-server.conf-sample.message:
Are these paths supposed to be quoted or anything? I'm trying to think of how you would specify "just this one container, which happens to have a star or a comma in it." I suppose the bucket naming rules help us, but what if the *account* is the one with the star or comma?

Do we want this mainly for the sake of trialing, but once we have more confidence we expect operators to allow inventories cluster-wide? Or do you see a long-term utility to this ability to filter? Makes me think a bit of https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/126049, where we deprecated an account-list-in-config for sysmeta...

swift/common/middleware/s3api/acl_handle.message:
I think we may want OWNER here -- from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/API_PutBucketInventoryConfiguration.html and https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/API_DeleteBucketInventoryConfiguration.html

> To use this operation, you must have permissions to perform the s3:PutInventoryConfiguration action. The bucket owner has this permission by default and can grant this permission to others

OTOH, the versioning stuff is also using WRITE... hmm :-/

swift/common/middleware/s3api/controller.message: i'd guess these limitations exist for compatibility with s3 - these are limitations of our proprietary implementation?
yes - s3 api mandates that format and inventory ID are included in the XML request body, but our backend only supports specific values.
what does s3 do if you make a inventroy request to an object?!
I'm setting up to do some cross-compatibility testing, I'll check this one when I can
Seems likely to be a reasonable limit. May need to bump it up as we add support for things like prefix filters and optional fields, but we can cross that bridge later.
Right; so we strip off the arn:aws:s3:... bit in __init__
OK, we don't have to worry about container names with a colon, because they would violate S3's bucket naming rules (even the old ones that allows upper case letters and underscores).

nit: Feels odd that we wouldn't do

 'Id must be %s' % DEFAULT_INVENTORY_ID

It bugs me how round-tripping an InventoryConfiguration through to_dict/from_dict or to_xml/from_xml isn't guaranteed to give you equivalent configs... Maybe I'm just over-eager to support multiple configs, though.
Was this comment copied from some other controller? I'm not sure (how) it applies here...
What if an operator has manually configured a second config? It wouldn't show up in listings, but if the client knew the id anyway, they'd be able to delete it, yeah? Is that... intended behavior?
So when (if ever) do soft-deleted configs get reaped?
Similar note as with DELETE: if an operator wanted to start testing allowing multiple inventories, (it looks like) a client could read the non-default inventory. Only we're gonna lie about the id :-/
